title: Exploring LSST Data: brightness vs distance

previous.title: Exploring LSST Data: flux vs distance

content: Now let’s look at the plot of brightness vs. distance for all of the objects observed by LSST. Notice that in the plot above there are galaxies at distances much greater than 13.8 billion light years away. But the Universe is only 13.8 billion years old. How can that happen?

question.title: Question #1
question.label: If it took 13 billion years for the light from a distant galaxy to travel to Earth, and the Universe wasn’t expanding, how far away would this galaxy be from Earth?
